title: In the reaction 2CO(g) + O 2(g) ---> 2CO 2(g), what is the ratio of moles of oxygen used to moles of CO 2 produced? - Quora

response.answer_text: Basing on the balanced chemical equation one mole of oxygen gas O2 produces 2 moles of carbon dioxide gas CO2. The mole ratio of the the oxygen gas to the carbon dioxide gas is 1:2. This is the beauty of a balanced chemical equation because the mole ratio of the reactants and the products are immediately seen.
Look at your correctly balanced equation: 2CO(g) + O 2(g)→ 2CO 2(g) 1mol O2 produces 2 mol CO2 Ratio: O:CO2 = 1:2
